text:
Nine years ago I was on the Great Barrier
Reef in Australia getting my SCUBA diving
certification.

First you dive for a couple of days in a pool
before you venture out into the ocean.

When it was time for my first ocean dive,
we went through our checklist making sure

we had all of our equipment, it was on properly,
we checked out buddies equipment and then…
we jumped in!

Over the next five or so minutes we descended
down to 18 metres (which is about 60 feet)
and then…
I ran out of air.

When we’re preparing for somewhat treacherous
activities, we always prepare for the worst
case scenario.
And then when it happens we know what to do.

Running out of air sounds terrifying in hindsight,
but it happened after days of training: of

learning sign language and of what to do in
the worst case scenarios.

So I swam over to my buddy, signalled that
I had no air and grabbed their spare regulator.

I didn’t freak out or have a panic attack,
I just fell back on my training and did what
I had been instructed to do.

We gradually rose to the surface to the comfort
of air and from that day on I always triple

check the air in my tank so I can be certain
I’ll make it.

This is a pretty extreme scenario, but one
that can happen in many different environments.

Fast forward a few years and I read this book
by Chris Hadfield – you probably remember

him as the astronaut from the amazing Space
Oddity video.

He offers lessons from space you can apply
to life, planning for the unknown and... uncertainty

And when I was reading it, I didn’t know
that I was about to be entering the most uncertain
period of my life.
Now, nobody really likes uncertainty.
But we all experience it.

And some people have a higher tolerance for
uncertainty than others.

In the book I mentioned, Chris Hadfield talks
about receiving a lot of training for every

conceivable scenario of things that could
go wrong on the international space station.

So if there was a fire on board, they would
know how to respond to the alarm calmly, isolate

the different sections of the spacecraft to
avoid damage and extinguish the fire without

their heartbeat increasing by a single beat
per minute.

On Earth, our uncertain situations are a little
different: perhaps you’re finishing school,

in an uncertain relationship or you’re concerned
you’ll lose your job.

Science shows we all have a different tolerance
for uncertainty.
(I’m guessing an astronauts is VERY high)

And to explore yours, I want you to imagine
a scenario:
I am giving away an envelope of money.

If you put up your hand up to win this envelope,
there’s a 50% chance that you could take
it home now.
I’m going to announce the winner today.

But, there’s always a twist, I’m also
giving away a second envelope of money too.

Now this one you have a higher chance of winning
more money, you have a 70% chance of taking
it home.

But I’ll be giving it away at a later date,
sometime in the future, you have no idea when.
So, which envelope do you choose?

50% [chance to win] now, or 70% [chance to
win] later.

For the best outcome, you should always choose
the larger reward where you have the largest
chance of receiving it.

But if you can’t deal with uncertainty,
or if you have a lower tolerance for risk,

you’ll be more likely to choose the smaller
reward, where you find out about it today.

This was done in a 2011 study where the researchers
found that people who had a high intolerance

of uncertainty - they couldn’t deal with
uncertainty – chose the immediate reward
that was less probably and smaller.

A fear of uncertainty can lead us to make
decisions that ultimately aren’t in our
own best interests.

We often react to uncertainty by freaking
out, by panicking and taking the fastest or
easiest option out.

This isn’t surprising because uncertainty
is stressful and we just want it to end!

Uncertainty can be even more stressful when
we know the outcome will be bad.

There was another study where people received
a small, but unpleasant, electric shock.

But in scenarios where they were uncertain
about whether they would receive the shock

or not, people’s stress levels were the
highest.

People would rather know they are going to
receive an electric shock than just be uncertain
about it.
And I can really relate to that now.

Rewind back to when I finished reading that
book.

I was about to leave a really stable job I
had with Australia’s science agency, I was

about to leave a country that offered free
healthcare and start my own business halfway
around the world.

I wanted to pursue a career on Youtube which,
as I soon realised, is filled with extreme
ups and downs and a ton of uncertainty.
I took a chance that was not the easiest option.

I’ve had to deal with a lot of that uncertainty
in recent years – applying for working permits

and waiting for mystery medical bills and
having work contracts end suddenly.

But through all of this I’ve learned about
how to deal with uncertainty and how to stay
positive.

There are some insights from both space and
earth that we can all use to embrace uncertainty.
Or at least deal with it a little bit better.

First, it’s important to identify which
of our uncertainty worries can be tackled

with problem solving and which worries are
about things that you just have no control
over.

Focusing on the things that you can change
may help you feel more in control

And then for things that are difficult to
control, I tend to think through potential

outcomes and form a few contingency plans:
If my work contract isn’t renewed I’ll
do X or Y or Z to deal with it.

This helps you prepare for the worst outcomes
so you have an action plan, however vague
it may be, if they do happen.

The reason I ran out of air when I was diving
is that my instructor handed me an empty tank.

And because he gave it to me, I didn’t think
to check it and then my buddy missed the check

and then, when we were going to jump off the
boat, the boat captain also forgot to check
my tank.

There were four points where this should have
stopped but they all failed.
And as a result I only had enough air to descend.
And practice was what got me through it.
Uncertainty in all of our lives is inevitable.

There will be some situations that you thought
you could control that you can’t, and times

where you kind of feel like you’re running
out of air.

Practice and planning can help you deal with
it, but most importantly, we can learn to
appreciate what we can control in life.
